sp.p: Why, Sir, I don't disapprove your Advice, but my Clerk is not here, and I can't Spell well.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: You may get it writ at your Leisure, and send it me. But because you are not much us'd to draw up Addresses, perhaps; I'll tell you in general, what kind of one this ought to be.
May it please Your Majesty—
(To the Gent.) You'll excuse me if I don't know your Name and Title.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir Polidorus Hogstye, of Beast-Hall, in Swine County.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Very well.

May it please your Majesty; Polidorus Hogstye, of Beast-Hall, in Swine County, most humbly represents, That he hates to Pay Taxes, the dreadful Consequences of 'em being inevitably these; That he must retrench two Dishes in Ten, where not above six of 'em are design'd for Gluttony.
Four Bottles out of Twenty; where not above fifteen of 'em are for Drunkenness.
Six Horses out of Thirty; of which not above Twenty are kept for State.
And four Servants out of a Score; where one half do nothing but make Work for t'other.
To this deplorable Condition must your Important Subject be reduc'd, or forc'd to cut down his Timber, which he wou'd willingly preserve, against an ill run at Dice.
And as to the necessity of the War, for the Security of the Kingdom; he neither knows, nor cares, whether it be necessary, or not.
He concludes, with his Prayers for Your Majesty's Life, upon condition, you will Protect him and his Fox-hounds, at Beast-Hall, without e'er a Penny of Money.
(To the Gent.) This, Sir, I suppose, is much what you wou'd be at.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Exactly, Sir, I'll be sure to have one drawn up, to the self same purpose; and next Fox-Hunting I'll engage half the Company shall set their Hands to't.

Sir, I am your— most devoted Servant; and if you please to let me see you at Beast-Hall, here's my Huntsman Houndsfoot will shew you a Fox, shall lead you through so many Hedges and Bryars, you shall have no more Cloaths on your Back in half an Hours time— than you had— in the Womb of your Mother. Haux, haux, haux, &c.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: O Tempora, O Mores!

div.stage: Enter Mr. Fruitful, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mr. F.
sp.p: Heavens preserve the Noble Aesop; grant him long Life and happy Days.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: And send him a fruitful Wise, with a hopeful Issue.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: And what is it I'm to do for you, good People, to make you amends for all these friendly wishes?

sp.speaker: Mr. F.
sp.p: Sir, here's my self and my Wife—

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Sir, here's I and my Husband— (to her Husband.) Let me speak in my turn, Goodman Forward.
(To Aes.) Sir, here's I and my Husband, I say, think we have as good Pretensions to the King's Favour, as ever a Lord in the Land.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: If you have no better than some Lords in the Land, I hope you won't expect much for your Service.

sp.speaker: Mr. F.
sp.p: An't please you, you shall be Judge your self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: That's as he gives Sentence, Mr. Little-wit; who gave you power to come to a Reference. If he does not do us Right, the King himself shall; what's to be done here?

(To Aes.) Sir, I'm forc'd to Correct my Husband a little; poor Man, he is not us'd to Court Business; but to give him his due, he's ready enough at some things: Sir, I have had twenty fine Children by him; fifteen of-em are alive, and alive like to be; five tall Daughters are wedded and bedded, and ten proper Sons serve their King and their Country.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: A goodly Company upon my word.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Would all Men take as much pains for the Peopling the Kingdom, we might tuck up our Aprons, and cry a Fig for our Enemies; but we have such a parcel of Drones amongst us— Hold up your Head, Husband— He's a little out of Countenance, Sir, because I chid him; but the Man's a very good Man at the bottom. But to come to my Business, Sir; I hope His Majesty will think it reasonable to allow me something for the Service I have done him; 'tis pity but Labour shou'd be encourag'd, especially when what one has done, one has don't with a good will.
(To Mr. F.) What Profession are you of, good People?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: My Husband's an Inn-keeper, Sir; he bares the Name, but I govern the House.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: And what Posts are your Sons in, in the Service?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Sir, there are four Monks.

sp.speaker: Mr. F.
sp.p: Three Attorneys.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Two Scriveners.

sp.speaker: Mr. F.
sp.p: And an Excise-man.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: The deux o' the Service; why, I thought they had been all in the Army.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Not one, Sir.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: No, so it seems, by my Troth: Ten Sons that serve their Country, quoth a, Monks, Attorneys, Scriveners and Excise men, serve their Country with a Vengeance; you deserve to be rewarded, truly; you deserve to be hang'd, you wicked People you. Get you gone out of my sight: I never was so angry in my Life.

sp.speaker: Mr. F.
sp.p: So; who's in the right now; you or I; I told you what wou'd come on't; you must be always a Breeding, and Breeding, and the King wou'd take care of 'em, and the Queen wou'd take care of 'em. And always some pretence or other there was. But now we have got a great Kennel of Whelps, and the Devil will take care of 'em, for ought I see. For your Sons are all Rogues, and your Daughters are all Whores, you know they are.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: What, you are a grudging of your Pains now, you Lazy, Sluggish, Flegmatick Drone. You have a mind to die of a Lethargy, have you? but I'll raise your Spirits for you, I will so. Get you gone home, go; go home you Idle Sot, you, I'll raise your Spirits for you.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Monks, Attorneys, Scriveners, and Excise-men.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: O here he is: Sir, I have been searching you, to say two Words to you.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: And now you have found me, Sir, what are they?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: They are, Sir— that my Name's Oronces; you comprehend me.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: I comprehend your Name.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: And not my Business?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Not I, by my Troth.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Then I shall endeavour to teach it you, Monsieur Aesop.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: And I to learn it, Monsieur Oronces.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Know, Sir— that I admire Euphronia.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Know, Sir— that you are in the right on't.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: But I pretend, Sir, that no Body else shall admire her.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Then I pretend, Sir, she won't admire you.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Why so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Because, Sir,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: She's a Woman, Sir.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, she desires to be admir'd by every Man she meets.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Sir, You are too familiar.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Sir, you are too haughty; I must soften that harsh tone of yours: It don't become you, Sir; it makes a Gentleman appear a Porter, Sir: And that you may know the use of good Language, I'll tell you what once happenn'd.
Once on a Time

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I'll have none of your old Wives Fables, Sir: I have no Time to lose; therefore, in a word—

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: In a word, be mild: For nothing else will do you Service. Good Manners and soft Words have brought many a difficult thing to pass. Therefore hear me patiently.

lg.l: A Cook one Day, who had been drinking,
(Only as many times you know,
You spruce, young witty Beaux will do,
T'avoid the dreadful pain of Thinking)
Had Orders sent him to behead
A Goose, like any Chaplain fed.
He took such Pains to set his Knife right,
'Thad done one good t'have lost ones Life by't.
But many Men, have many Minds,
There's various Tasts in various Kinds;
A Swan (who by mistake he seiz'd)
With wretched Life was better pleas'd.
For as he went to give the Blow,
In tuneful Notes, she let him know,
She neither was a Goose, nor wisht
To make her Exit so.
The Cook (who thought of nought but Blood,
Except it were the Grease,
For that you know's his Fees)
To hear her sing, in great Amazement stood.
Cods Fish, quoth he, 'twas well you spoke,
For I was just upon the stroke.
Your Feathers have so much of Goose,
A Drunken Cook cou'd do no less,
Then think you one; That you'll Confess.
But y'ave a Voice, so soft, so sweet,
That rather than you shall be eat,
The House shall Starve for want of Meat
And so he turn'd her loose.

sp.p: (To Or.) Now, Sir, what say you? Will you be the Swan, or the Goose?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The Choice can't, sure, be difficult to make,
I hope you will excuse my Youthful heat,
Young Men and Lovers, have a Claim to Pardon
But since the faults of Age have no such Plea,
I hope you'll be more Cautious of offending.
The Flame that warms Euphronia's Heart and mine
Has long, alas! been kindled in our Breasts,
Even Years are past, since our two Souls were wed,
Twou'd be Adultery, but to wish to part 'em.
And wou'd a Lump of Clay alone content you,
A Mistress Cold and Senseless in your Arms,
Without the least remains or signs of Life
Except her Sighs, to Mourn her Absent Lover.
Whilst you shou'd press her in your eager Arms,
With fond desire and extasie of Love,
Wou'd it not pierce you to the very Soul;
To see her Tears run trickling down her Cheeks,
And know their Fountain, meant 'em all to me?
Cou'd you bare this?
Yet thus the Gods revenge themselves on those
Who stop the happy Course of mutual Love.
If you must be Unfortunate one way,
Chuse that, where Justice may support your Grief,
And shun the weighty Curse of Injur'd Lovers.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.l: Why, this is pleading like a Swan indeed—
Were any thing at Stake but my Euphronia—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Your Euphronia Sir—

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.l: The Goose— take heed—
Were any thing, I say, at stake but her;
Your Plea wou'd be too strong to be refus'd.
But our Debate's about a Lady, Sir,
That's Young, that's Beautiful, that's made for Love
sp.p: — So am not I you'll say? But y'are mistaken, Sir; I'm made to Love, tho' not to be belov'd. I have a Heart like yours; I've folly too: I've every Instrument of Love like others.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: But, Sir, you have not been long a Lover,
Your Passion's young and tender,
'Tis easie for you to become its Master.
Whilst I shou'd strive in vain, mine's Old and Fixt,

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: The older 'tis, the easier to be govern'd,
Were mine of as long a standing, 'twere possible I might get the better on't. Old Passions are like Old Men; Weak, and soon jostled into the Channel.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Yet Age sometimes is strong, even to the Verge of Life.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Ay, but there our Comparison don't hold.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: You are too merry to be much in Love.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: And you too sad to be so long.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: My Grief may end my days, so quench my Flame; but nothing else can e'er extinguish it.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Don't be discourag'd Sir; I have seen many a Man out-live his Passion Twenty Years.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: But I have Sworn, to dye Euphronia's Slave.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: A decay'd Face always absolves a Lovers Oath.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Lovers whose Oaths are made to Faces then: But 'tis Euphronia's Soul that I adore, which never can decay.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: I wou'd fain see a young Fellow in Love with a Soul of Threescore.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Quit but Euphronia to me, and you shall,
At least if Heaven's Bounty will afford us
But Years enough to prove my Constancy,
And this is all I ask the Gods and you.

sp.speaker: Aesop
sp.l: A good pretence however, to beg a long Life.
How grosly do the Inclinations of the Flesh,
Impose upon the simplicity of the Spirit?
sp.p: Had this young Fellow but studied Anatomy, he'd have found the Source of his Passion lay far from his Mistress's Soul.
sp.l: Alas, Alas!
Had Women no more Charms in their Bodies,
Than what they have in their Minds,
We shou'd see more wise Men in the World,
Much fewer Lovers and Poets.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: heavens, what is't you make me do, Doris? Apply my self to the Man I loath; beg Favours from him I hate; seek a Reprieve from him I abhor? 'Tis low, 'tis mean, 'tis base in me.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Why, you hate the Devil as much as you do Aesop, (or within a small matter) and shou'd you think it a scandal to pray him to let you alone a day or two, if he were a going to run away with you; ha?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I don't know what I think, nor what I say, nor what I do: But sure, th'art not my Friend, thus to advise me.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: I advise? I advise nothing; e'en follow your own way, marry him and make much of him. I have a mind to see some of his Breed; if you like it, I like it: He shan't breed out of me only; that's all I have to take care of.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Prithee don't distract me.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Why, to morrow's the day, fix'd and firm, you know it; Much Meat, little Order, great many Relations, few Friends, Horse-play, Noise, and bawdy Stories; all's ready for a compleat Wedding.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Oh, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Nay, I know this makes you tremble; and yet your tender Conscience scruples to drop one Hypocritical Cursy, and say, 'pray, Mr. Aesop, be so kind to defer it a few days longer.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Thou know'st I cannot dissemble.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p:
I know you can dissemble well enough, when you shou'd not do't. Do you remember how you us'd to plague your poor Oronces; make him believe you loath'd him, when you cou'd have kiss'd the ground he went on; affront him in all publick
Places; ridicule him in all Company; abuse him where-ever you went; and when you had reduc'd him within Ams Ace of hanging or drowning, then come home with Tears in your Eyes, and cry, now, Doris, let's go lock our selves up, and talk of my dear Oronces. Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes. But, prithee, have some Compassion on me. Come, I'll do any thing thou bidd'st me— What shall I say to this Monster? Tell me, and I'll obey thee.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Nay, then there's some hopes of you.

Why, you must tell him— 'Tis natural to you to dislike Folks at first sight: That since you have consider'd him better, you find your Aversion abated: That though perhaps it may be a hard matter for you ever to think him a Beau, you don't despair in time of finding out his Iene scai quoy. And that on t'other side; tho' you have hitherto thought (as most young Women do) that nothing cou'd remove your first Affection, yet you have very great hopes in the natural Inconstancy of your Sex.

Tell him, 'tis not impossible a change may happen, provided he gives you time: But that if he goes to force you, there's another piece of Nature peculiar to Woman, which may chance to spoil all, and that's Contradiction: Ring that Argument well in his Ears: He's a Philosopher, he knows it has weight in't.

In short, Wheedle, whine, flatter, lye, weep, spare nothing, it's a moist Age, Women have Tears enough; and when you have melted him down, and gain'd more time, we'll employ it in Closet-Debates how to cheat him to the end of the Chapter.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: But you don't consider, Doris, that by this means I engage my self to him; and can't afterwards with Honour retreat.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Madam, I know the World— Honour ' a Jest, when Jilting's useful.

Besides, he that wou'd have you break your Oath with Oronces, can never have the Impudence to blame you for cracking your Word with himself. But who knows what may happen between the Cup and the Lip. Let either of the Old Gentlemen dye, and we ride triumphant. Wou'd I cou'd but see the Statesman sick a little, I'd recommend a Doctor to him, a Cousin of mine, a Man of Conscience, a wise Physician; tip but the Wink, he understands you.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Thou wicked Wench, woud'st poison him?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: I don't know what I wou'd do, I think, I study, I invent, and some how I will get rid of him. I do more for you, I'm sure, than you and your Knight Errant do together for your selves.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Alas, both he and I do all we can; thou know'st we do.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Nay, I know y'are willing enough to get together; but y'are a couple of helpless Things, Heaven knows.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Our Stars, thou see'st, are bent to Opposition.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Stars!— I'd fain see the Stars hinder me from running away with a Man I lik'd.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Ay, But thou know'st, shou'd I disoblige my Father, he'd give my Portion to my younger Sister.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Ay, there the Shooe pinches, there's the Love of the Age; Ah!— to what an Ebb of Passion are Lovers sunk in these days. Give me a Woman that runs away with a Man, when his whole Estate's pack'd up in his Snap-sack. That tucks up her Coats to her Knees; and through thick and through thin, from Quarters to Camp trudges heartily on, with a Child at her Back, another in her Arms, and a brace in her Belly: There's Flame with a Witness, where this is the Effects on't. But we must have Love in a Feather-bed, Forsooth, a Coach and Six Horses, Clean Linen, and a Cawdle; Fie, for shame.
O ho, here comes our Man. Now shew your self a Woman, if you are one.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: I'm told, fair Virgin, you desire to speak with me. Lovers are apt to flatter themselves: I take your Message for a Favour. I hope 'twas meant so.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Favours from Women are so cheap of late, Men may expect 'em truly without Vanity.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: If the Women are so liberal, I think the Men are generous too on their side: 'Tis a well-bred Age, thank Heaven; and a deal of Civility there passes between the two Sexes. What Service is't that I can do you, Lady?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Sir, I have a small Favour to intreat you.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: What is't? I don't believe I shall refuse you.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: What, if you shou'd promise me you won't.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Why, then I shou'd make a Divorce between my good Breeding and my Sence, which ought to be as sacred a Knot as that of Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Dare you not trust then, Sir, the thing you love?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Not when the thing I love don't love me; never.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Trust is sometimes the way to be belov'd.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Ay, but 'tis oftner the way to be cheated.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Pray promise me you'll grant my suit.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: 'Tis a reasonable one, I give you my word for't.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: If it be so, I do promise to grant it.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: That's still leaving your self Judge.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Why, who's more concern'd in the Tryal?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: But no body ought to be Judge in their own Cause.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Yet he that is so, is sure to have no wrong done him.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: But if he does wrong to others, that's worse.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Worse for them, but not for him.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: True Politician, by my troth!

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Men must be so, when they have to do with Sharpers.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: If I should tell you then, there were a possibility, I might be brought to love you, you'd scarce believe me?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: I shou'd hope as a Lover, and suspect as a Statesman.
Do. aside.] Love and Wisdom! There's the Passion of the Age again.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: You have liv'd long, Sir, and observ'd much: Did you never see Time produce strange Changes?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Amongst Women I must confess I have.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Why, I'm a Woman, Sir.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Why, truly that gives me some hopes.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I'll encrease 'em, Sir; I have already been in love two years.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: And Time, you know, wears all things to tatters.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Well observ'd.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: What if you shou'd allow me some, to try what I can do?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Why, truly, I wou'd have patience a day or two, if there were as much probability of my being your new Gallant, as perhaps there may be of changing your old one.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: She shall give you fair play for't, Sir; Opportunity and leave to prattle, and that's what carries most Women in our days. Nay, she shall do more for you. You shall play with her Fan; squeese her little Finger; buckle her Shooe; read a Romance to her in the Arbour; and saunter in the Woods, on a Moon-shiny Night. If this don't melt her, she's no Woman; or you no Man—

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: I'm not a Man to melt a Woman that way: I know my self, and know what they require. 'Tis through a Woman's Eye you pierce her Heart. And, I've no Darts can make their entrance there.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: You are a great Statesman, Sir; but I find you know little of our Matters. A womans heart's to be enter'd forty ways. Every Sence she has about her, keeps a door to't. With a Smock-face, and a Feather, you get in at her Eyes. With powerful Nonsence, in soft words, you creep in at her Ears. An Essenc'd Peruke, and a Sweet Handkerchief, lets you in at her Nose. With a Treat, and a Box full of Sweet-meats, you slip in at her Mouth: And if you would enter by her Sense of Feeling, 'tis as beaten a Road as the rest. What think you now, Sir? There are more ways to the Wood than one, you see.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Why, y'are an admirable Pilot: I don't doubt but you have fleer'd many a Ship safe to Harbour: But I'm an old stubborn Sea-man; I must sail by my own Compass still.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: And, by your Obstinacy, lose your Vessel.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: No: I'm just entring into Port; we'll be married tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: For Heavens sake, deferr it some days longer: I cannot love you yet, indeed I cannot.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Nor never will, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Why then will you marry me?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Because I love you.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: If you lov'd me, you wou'd never make me miserable.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Not if I lov'd you for your sake; but I love you for my own.
Do. aside.] Theres an old Rogue for you.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Is there no way left? Must I be wretched?

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: 'Tis but resolving to be pleas'd. You can't imagine the strength of Resolution. I have seen a Woman resolve to be in the wrong, all the days of her life; And by the help of her Resolution, she has kept her word to a tittle.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Methinks, the Subject we're upon, shou'd be of weight enough to make you serious.

sp.speaker: Es.
sp.p: Right: To morrow morning pray be ready: You'll find me so: I'm serious: Now I hope you are pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.stage: Going off weeping, and leaning upon Doris.]
sp.p: Break Heart! For if thou hold'st, I'm miserable.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Now my the Extravagance of a lewd Wife, with the Insolence of a Vertuous one, join hand in hand to bring thy Grey Hairs to the Grave.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: My old Friend wishes me well to the last I see.

div.stage: Enter Learcus hastily, follow'd by Oronces.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Pray hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain: I'm resolv'd, I tell thee.

Most Noble Aesop, since you are pleas'd to accept of my poor Off-spring for your Consort, be so charitable to my Old Age, to deliver me from the Impertinence of Youth, by making her your Wife this Instant; for there's a Plot against my Life; they have resolv'd to teaze me to Death to night, that they may break the Match to morrow morning. Marry her this Instant, I intreat you.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: This Instant, say you?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: This Instant; this very Instant.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: 'Tis enough; get all things ready; I'll be with you in a moment.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Now, what say you, Mr. Flame-Fire? I shall have the whip-hand of you presently.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Defer it but till to morrow, Sir.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: That you may run away with her to night, ha?—
Sir, your most Obedient, Humble Servant.
Hey; who waits there? Call my Daughter to me: Quick.
I'll give her her Dispatches presently.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: D'ye call, Sir?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Yes; I do, Minx. Go shift your self, and put on your best Cloaths. You are to be marry'd.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Marry'd Sir?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Yes, marry'd, Madam; and that this Instant too.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Dear Sir!

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Not a word: Obedience and a clean-Smock. Dispatch.
sp.stage: Learcus going off, turns to Oronces.
sp.p: Sir, your most Obedient Humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Yet hear what I've to say.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: And what have you to say, Sir.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Alas! I know not what I have to say!

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Very like so. That's a sure sign he's in Love now.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Have you no Bowels?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Ha, ha! Bowels in a Parent! Here's a young Fellow for you. Hark thee, Stripling. Being in a very merry humour, I don't care if I discover some Paternal Secrets to thee.

Know then; that how humoursome, how whimsical soever we may appear, there's one fixt Principle that runs through almost the whole Race of us; and that's to please our selves. Why do'st think I got my Daughter? Why, there was something in't that pleas'd me. Why do'st think I marry my Daughter? Why, to please my self still. And what is't that pleases me? Why, my Interest, what do'st think it shou'd be? If Aesop's my Son-in-Law, he'll make me a Lord: If thou art my Son-in-Law thou'lt make me a Grand-father. Now I having more Mind to be a Lord than a Grand-father, give my Daughter to him, and not to thee.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Then shall her Happiness weigh nothing with you?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Not this: If it did, I'd give her to thee, and not to him.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Do you think forc'd Marriage the way to keep Women Vertuous?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: No; nor I don't care whether Women are Vertuous or not.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: You know your Daughter loves me.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I do so.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: What if the Children that Aesop may happen to Father, shou'd chance to be begot by me?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Why, then Aesop wou'd be the Cuckold, not I.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Is that all you care?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Yes: I speak as a Father.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: What think you of your Child's Concern in t'other world?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Why, I think it my Child's Concern, not mine. I speak as a Father.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Do you remember you once gave me your Consent to wed your Daughter?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Why did you so?

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: Because you were the best Match that offer'd at that time. I did like a Father.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, I'll do like a Lover. I'll make you keep your Word, or cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Who waits there, Hey?
Seize me that Bully there. Carry him to Prison, and keep him safe.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Why, you won't use me thus?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Yes, but I will tho': Away with him. Sir, your most Humble Servant: I wish you a good Nights Rest; and as far as a merry Dream goes, my Daughter's at your Service.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Death and Furies!

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: Dol, de tol dol, dol dol, de tol dol:
Lilly Burleighre's lodg'd in a Bough.

div.stage: Enter a Troop of Musicians, Dancers, &c.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: How now? What have we got here?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Sir, we are a Troop of Trifling Fellows, Fidlers, and Dancers, come to celebrate the Wedding of your Fair Daughter: If your Honour pleases to give us leave.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: With all my Heart: But who do you take me for, Sir; Ha?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I take your Honour for our Noble Governour of Sysicus.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Governour of Sysicus; Governour of a Cheese-Cake! I'm Father-in-law to the Great Aesop, Sirrah.
Aside.]— I shall be a Great Man.
Come, Tune your Fiddles; Shake your Legs; Get all things ready. My Son-in-Law will be here presently— I shall be a great Man.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: A great Marriage, Brother: What do'st think will be the end on't?

sp.speaker: 2 Mus.
sp.p: Why, I believe we shall see three turns upon't. This Old Fellow here, will turn Fool; his Daughter will turn Strumpet; and his Son-in-Law will turn 'em both out of doors. But that's nothing to thee nor me, as long as we are paid for our Fidling. So tune away, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1. Mus.
sp.p: D'ye hear Trumpets? When the Bride appears, salute her with a melancholy Waft. 'Twill suit her humour; for I guess she mayn't be over-well pleas'd.

div.stage: Enter Learcus with several Friends, and a Priest.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Friends, y'are all welcome. I have sent to as many of you, as our short time wou'd give me leave, to desire you wou'd be Witnesses of the Honour the Great Aesop designs our self and Family. Hey; who attends there?
Go, let my Daughter know I wait for her.
— 'Tis a vast Honour that is done me, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: It is indeed, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Look you there; if they don't call me my Lord already— I shall be a great Man.

div.stage: Enter Euphronia weeping, and leaning upon Doris, both in deep Mourning.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: How now? What's here? All in deep Mourning? Here's a provoking Baggage for you.

div.stage: [The Trumpets sound a-melancholy Air till Aesop appears; and then the Violins and Hautbois strike up a Lancashire Hornpipe.
Enter Aesop in a Gay, Foppish Dress, long Peruke, &c. a Gaudy Equipage of Pages and Footmen, all enter, in an airy, brisk manner.

sp.speaker: Aesop
sp.stage: in an affected Tone, to Euphronia.]
sp.p: Gad take my Soul, Mame, I hope I shall please you now.— Gentlemen all, I'm your Humble Servant. I'm going to be a very happy Man you see.
To Eu.] When the Heat of the Ceremonies over, if your Ladyship pleases, Mame; I'll wait upon you to take the Air in the Park. Hey, Page; Let there be a Coach and six Horses ready instantly.

Observing her Dress.]— I vow to Gad, Mame, I was so taken up with my good Fortune, I did not observe the extream Fancy of your Ladyship's Wedding-Cloaths— Infinitely pretty, as I hope to be sav'd: a World of Variety, and not at all gawdy.
To L. My Dear Father-in-Law. Embrace me.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Your Lordship does me too much Honour. Aside.]— I shall be a great Man.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, Are all things ready? Where's the Priest?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Here, my Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Most Reverend— Will you please to say Grace that I may fall to, for I'm very hungry, and here's very good Meat. But where's my Rival all this while? The least we can do, is to invite him to the Wedding.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: My Lord, he's in Prison.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: In Prison! how so?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: He wou'd have murder'd me.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: A bloody Fellow! But let's see him however. Send for him quickly.
Ha, Governor— that handsome Daughter of yours, I will so mumble her—

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I shall be a great Man.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: O ho: Here's my Rival: Then we have all we want. Advance, Sir, if you please. I desire you'll do me the Favour to be a Witness to my Marriage, lest one of these days you shou'd take a Fancy to dispute my Wife with me.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Do you then send for me to insult me: 'Tis base in you.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: I have no time now to throw away upon Points of Generosity; I have hotter Work upon my hands. Come, Priest, advance.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Pray hold him fast there; he has the Devil and all of Mischief in's Eye.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Will your Ladyship please, Mame, to give me your fair hand— hey-day.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I'll give it you, my Noble Lord, if she won't. Aside.] A stubborn, self-will'd, stiff-necked Strumpet.

div.stage: [Learcus holds out her Hand to Aesop, who takes it; Oronces stands on Aesop's left hand, and the Priest before 'em.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Let my Rival stand next me: Of all Men I'd have him be satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Barbarous Inhumane Monster.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: Now, Priest do thy Office.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Since the Eternal Laws of Fate decree,
That He, thy Husband; She, thy Wife shou'd be.
May Heaven take you, to its Care.
May Iupiter look kindly down,
Place on your Heads Contentments Crown;
And may his Godhead never frown
Upon this Happy Pair.

div.stage: [As the Priest pronounces the last Line, Aesop joins Oronces and Euphronia's hands.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: O happy Change: Blessings on Blessings wait on the Generous Aesop.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.l: Happy, thrice happy may you ever be.
And if you think, there's something due to me,
Pay it in mutual Love and Constancy.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: You'll pardon me, most Generous Man, if in the present Transports of my Soul, which you your self have by your Bounty caus'd, my willing Tongue is ty'd from uttering the Thoughts that flow from a most grateful Heart.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.l: For what I've done, I merit little Thanks,
Since what I've done, my Duty bound me to.
I wou'd your Father had acquitted his:
But he who's such a Tyrant o'er his Children,
To sacrifice their Peace to his Ambition,
Is fit to govern nothing but himself.
To L] And therefore, Sir, at my return to Court,
I shall take Care this City may be sway'd
By more Humanity than dwells in you.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I shall be a great Man.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Had I not reason, from your Constant Goodness,
To judge your Bounty, Sir, is infinite,
I shou'd not dare to sue for farther Favours,
But pardon me; if imitating Heaven and you,
I easily forgive my Aged Father,
And beg that Aesop wou'd forgive him too.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: The Injury he wou'd have done to you, was great indeed: But 'twas a Blessing he design'd for me; if therefore you can pardon him, I may.

To L.] Your injur'd Daughter, Sir, has on her Knees intreated for her cruel, barbarous Father; and by her Goodness has obtain'd her Suit. If in the Remnant of your days, you can find out some
way to recompence her, do it, That Men and Gods may pardon you, as she and I have done. But let me see, I have one Quarrel still to make up. Where's my old Friend, Doris.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: She's here, Sir, at your Service; and as much your Friend as ever: True to her Principles, and firm to her Mistress. But she has a much better Opinion of you now than she had half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p: She has reason: For my Soul appear'd then as deform'd as my Body. But I hope now, one may so far mediate for t'other, that, provided I don't make Love, the Women won't quarrel with me; for they are worse Enemies even than they are Friends.
Come, Gentlemen, I'll humour my Dress a little longer, and share with you in the Diversions these Boon Companions have prepar'd us. Let's take our Places, and see how they can divert us.

div.stage: Aesop leads the Bride to her Place. All being seated, there's a short Consort of Hautboys, Trumpets, &c. After which a Dance between an Old Man and a young Woman, who shuns him still as he comes near her. At last he stops, and begins this Dialogue; which they sing together.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Why so Cold, and why so Coy.
What I wont in Youth and Fire,
I have in Love and in Desire:
To my Arms, my Love, my Ioy;
Why so Cold, and why so Coy?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: 'Tis Sympathy perhaps with you;
You are Cold, and I'm so too.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: My Years alone have froze my Blood;
Youthful Heat in Female Charms,
Glowing in my Aged Arms,
Wou'd melt it down once more into a Flood.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: Women, alas, like Flints, ne'er burn alone,
To make a Virgin know,
There's Fire within the Stone,
Some Manly Steel must boldly strike the Blow.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Assist me only with your Charms,
You'll find I'm Man, and still am bold;
You'll find I still can strike, tho' old:
I only want your Aid to raise my Arm.

div.stage: Enter a Youth who seizes on the young Woman.

sp.speaker: Youth.
sp.l: Who talks of Charms, who talks of Aid.
I bring an Arm
That wants no Charm,
To rouse the Fire that's in a Flinty Maid.
Retire Old Age.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: — Winter be gone:
Behold the Youthful Spring comes gayly on.
Here, here's a Torch, to light a Virgin's Fire:
To my Arms, my Love, my Ioy;
When Women have what they desire,
They're neither Cold nor Coy.

div.stage: The Song and Dance ended, Aesop takes Euphronia and Oronces by the Hands, leading them forwards.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.p:
By this time, my young eager Couple, 'tis probable you wou'd be glad to be alone; perhaps you'll have a mind to go to Bed even without your Supper; for Brides and Bridegrooms eat little on their Wedding-night. But since, if Matrimony were worn as it ought to be, it wou'd perhaps sit easier about us than
usually it does. I'll give you one Word of Council, and so I shall release you.
When one is out of Humour, let the other be dumb.
Let your Diversions be such, as both may have a share in 'em.
Never let Familiarity exclude Respect.
Be clean in your Cloaths, but nicely so in your Persons: Eat at one Table: Lye in one Room, but sleep in two Beds.
I'll tell the Ladies why.
sp.l: In the sprightly Month of May,
When Males and Females sport and play,
And Kiss and Toy away the Day.
An eager Sparrow and his Mate,
Chirping on a Tree were sate,
Full of Love— and full of Prate.
They talk't of nothing but their Fires,
Of Raging Heats, and Strong Desires,
Of Eternal Constancy;
How true and faithful they wou'd be,
Of this and that, and endless Joys,
And a thousand more such Toys.
The only thing they apprehended,
Was that their Lives wou'd be so short,
They cou'd not finish half their Sport
Before their Days were ended.
But, as from Bow to Bow they rove,
They chanc'd at last
In furious haste,
On a Twigg, with Birdlime spread;
(Want of a more downy Bed)
To act a Scene of Love.
Fatal it prov'd, to both their Fires.
For tho' at length they broke away,
And baulk'd the School-Boy of his Prey,
Which made him weep the live-long Day.
The Bridegroom, in the hasty strife,
Was stuck so fast, to his dear Wife;
That tho' he us'd his utmost Art,
He quickly found, it was in vain,
To put himself to farther Pain,
They never more must part.
A gloomy Shade o'recast his Brow;
He found himself— I know not how,
He look'd— as Husbands often do.
Where-e'er he mov'd, he felt her still,
She kiss'd him ost, against his Will:
Abroad, at Home; at Bed and Board;
With Favours she o'rewhelm'd her Lord.
Oft he turn'd his Head away,
And seldom had a word to say,
Which absolutely spoil'd her Play,
For she was better stor'd.
Howe'er, at length her Stock was spent,
(For Female Fires sometimes may be
Subject to Mortality;)
So Back to Back they sit, and sullenly Repent,
But the Mute Scene was quickly ended,
The Lady for her share pretended,
The want of Love lay at his Door,
For her part, she had still in store
Enough for him, and twenty more,
Which cou'd not be contented.
He answer'd her, in homely words,
(For Sparrows are but ill bred Birds)
That he already had enjoy'd
So much, that truly he was Cloy'd.
Which so provok'd her Spleen,
That after some good hearty Prayers,
A Jostle, and some spightful Tears
They fell together by the Ears,
And ne'r were fond again.

div.head: AESOP.
PART II.

sp.speaker: Aes.
sp.l: WELL, good People, who are all you?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Sir, we are Players—

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: Players? What Players?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Why, Sir, we are Stage-Players,
That's our Calling:
Tho' we play upon other things too; some of us play
Upon the Fiddle; some play upon the Flute;
We play upon one another, we play upon the Town,
And we play upon the Patentees.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: Patentees! Prithee, what are they?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Why, they are, Sir— Sir, they are—! Cod I don't know
What they are— Fish or Flesh— Masters or Servants
— Sometimes one— Sometimes t'other, I think—
Just as we are in the Mood.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: Why, I thought they had a lawful Authority over you.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Lawful Authority, Sir— Sir, we are freeborn Englishmen,
We care not for Law nor Authority neither,
When we are out of Humour.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: But I think they pretended at least to an Authority
Over you; 'pray' upon what Foundation was it built?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Upon a rotten one— if you'll believe us?
Sir, I'll tell you what the Projectors did:
They imbark'd Twenty thousand pound upon a Leaky
Vessel— She was built at Whitehall;
I think they call'd her— the Patent— ay, the Patent;
Her Keel was made of a Broad Seal— and the King
Gave 'em a White Staff for their Main Mast.
She was a pretty tight Frigat to look upon, indeed:
They spar'd nothing to set her off; they Guilded her,
And Painted her, and Rigg'd, and Gunn'd her;
And so sent her a Privateering.
But the first Storm that blew,
Down went the Mast, a-shore went the Ship—
Crack says the Keel, merry cry'd the Pilot;
But the Wind was so high, his Prayers cou'd not
Be heard— so they split upon a Rock—
That lay hid under a Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: A very sad Story, this: but what became of the
Ship's Company?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Why, Sir, your humble Servants here, who were
The Officers and the best of the Sailors—
(Little Ben amongst the rest) seiz'd on a small
Bark that lay to our hand, and away we put to see again.
To say the Truth, we were better Man'd than
Rigg'd, and Ammunition was plaguy scarce amongst
Us— However, a-Cruising we went, and some petty
Small Prizes we have made; but the Blessing
Of Heaven not being among us—
Or how the Devil 'tis, I can't tell; but we are not rich.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Well, but what became of the rest of the Crew?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Why, Sir, as for the Scoundrels, they, poor Dogs,
Stuck by the Rack. The Captain gave'em Bread,
And Cheese, and good Words— He told them, if they
Wou'd patch her up, and venture t'other Cruise;
He'd prefer 'em all; so to work they went,
And to Sea they got her.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: I hope he kept his Word with 'em.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: That he did; he made the Boat-Swain's Mate,
Lieutenant; he made the Cook, Doctor: He was
Forc'd to be Purser, and Pilot, and Gunner himself;
And the Swabber took Orders to be Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: But with such unskilful Officers I'm afraid
They'll hardly keep above Water long.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Why truly, Sir, we care not how soon they are under:
But Curst Folks, thrive, I think. I know nothing else
That makes 'em swim.
I'm sure, by the Rules of Navigation, they ought to
Have over-set long since; for they carry a great deal
Of Sail, and have very little Ballast.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: I'm afraid you ruine one another. I fancy if you
Were all in a Ship together again, you'd have less
Work and more Profit.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Ah, Sir— we are resolv'd we'll never sail under
Captain Patentee again.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Prithee, why so?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: Sir, he has us'd us like Dogs.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: — And Bitches too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: I'm sorry to hear that; 'pray' how was't he treated
You?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis impossible to tell; he us'd us like the English
At Amboyna—

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: But I wou'd know some Particulars; tell me what
'Twas he did to you.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: What he did, Sir— why, he did in the first place, Sir—
— In the first place, Sir, he did— I Cod I don't know what
He did— Can you tell, Wife?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Yes, marry can I; and a Burning Shame it was too.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: O, I remember now, Sir, he wou'd not give us Plumbs
Enough in our Pudding.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: That indeed was very hard; but did he give you as
Many as he promis'd you.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Yes, and more; but what of all that, we had not as
Many as we had a Mind to—

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: Sir, my Husband tells you Truth—

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: I believe he may; but what other wrongs did he do you?

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.l: Why, Sir, he did not treat me with respect; 'twas not
One Day in three, he wou'd so much as bid me good Morrow—

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.p: Sir, he invited me to Dinner, and never drank my health.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.l: Then he cock'd his Hat at Mrs. Pert.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.l: Yes, and told Mrs. Slippery he had as good a Face
As she had.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: Why, these were insufferable Abuses—

sp.speaker: 2 Play.
sp.l: Then, Sir, I did but come to him one day—
And tell him I wanted Fifty Pound, and what do you
Think he did by me, Sir—
Sir he turn'd round upon Heel like a Top—

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.l: But that was nothing to the Affront he put upon me, Sir.
I came to him, and in very civil Words, as I thought,
Desir'd him to double my Pair: Sir, wou'd you believe it,
He had the Barbarity to ask me, if I intended
To double my work; and because I told him, No,
Sir— he did use me, good Lord, how he did use me.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: Prithee how?

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.l: Why, he walk'd off and answer'd me never a Word.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: How had you Patience.

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.l: Sir, I had not Patience. I sent him a Challenge;
And what do you think his Answer was— he sent me Word
I was a Scoundrel Son of a Whore,
And he wou'd only fight me by Proxy—

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: Very fine.

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.l: At this rate, Sir; were we poor Dogs us'd— till one
Frosty Morning down he comes amongst us— and
Very roundly tells us— That for the Future,
No Purchase, no Pay. They that wou'd not work shou'd
Not eat—
Sir, we at first ask'd him cooly and civilly— Why?
His Answer was, because the Town wanted
Diversion, and he wanted Money—
Our Reply to this, Sir, was very short; but I think
To the purpose.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: What was it?

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.l: It was, Sir, that so we wallow'd in Plenty— and Ease
The Town and he might be damn'd—
This, Sir, is the true History of Seperation— and we
Hope you'll stand our Friend—

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: I'll tell you what, Sirs—
I once a Pack of a Beagles knew—
That much resembled, I know who:
With a good Huntsman at their Tail,
In full Command,
With Whip in Hand.
They'd run apace
The Chearful Chace,
And of their Game were seldom known to fail.
But being at length their chance to find
A Huntsman of a gentler Kind,
They soon perceiv'd the Rein was slack,
The Word went quickly through the Pack—
They one and all cry'd Liberty:
This happy Moment we are free.
We'll range the Woods,
Like Nymphs and Gods,
And spend our Mouths in praise of Mutiny.
With that old Iowler trots away,
And Bowman singles out his Prey.
Thunder bellow'd through the Wood,
And swore he'd burst his Guts with Blood.
Venus tript it o'er the Plain,
With boundless Hopes of boundless Gain.
— Iuno, she slipt down the Hedge,
But left her Sacred Word for Pledge;
That all she pickt up by the by—
Shou'd to the Publick Treasury.
And well they might rely upon her;
For Iuno was a Bitch of Honour.
In short, they all had hopes to see
A Heavenly Crop of Mutiny,
And so to Reaping fell:
But in a little time they found,
It was the Devil had Till'd the ground,
And brought the Seed from Hell.
The Pack divided, nothing throve;
Discord seiz'd the Throne of Love.
Want and Misery all endure,
All take pains, and all grow poor.
When they had toyl'd the live-long day,
And came at night, to view their Prey.
Oft alas so ill they'd sped,
That half went supperless to Bed.
At length they all in Council sate,
Where at a very fair Debate,
It was agreed at last,
That Slavery, with Ease and Plenty,
When Hounds were something turn'd of twenty,
Was much a better Fate,
Than 'twas to work and Fast.

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.l: Well, Sir— and what did they do then?

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: Why they all went home to their Kennel again.
If you think they did wisely, you'll do well to follow their Example.

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.p: Well Beagles; What think you of the little Gentleman's Advice.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.p: In think he's a little ugly Philosopher, and talks like a Fool.

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.p: Ay, why there's it now! If he had been a tall handsome Blockhead, he had talk'd like a Wise Man.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.p: Why, do you think, Mr. Iouler, that we'll ever joyn again?

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.p: I do think, sweet Mrs. Iuno, that if we do not joyn again, you must be a little freer of your Carcass than you are, or you must bring down your Pride to a Serge Petticoat.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.p: And do you think, Sir, after the Affronts I have receiv'd, the Patent and I can ever be Friends?

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.p: I do think, Madam, that if my Interest had not been more affronted than your Face, the Patent and you had never been Foes.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.p: And so, Sir, then you have serious thoughts of a Reconciliation!

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.p: Madam, I do believe I may.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, give me leave to tell you, that— make it my Interest, and I'll have serious thoughts on't too.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.p: Nay, if you are thereabouts, I desire to come into the Treaty.

sp.speaker: 3 Play.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: 4 Play.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: 2 Play.
sp.p: And I, no separate Peace. None of your Turin Play, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: 1 Play.
sp.l: Why then, since you are all so Christianly dispos'd—
I think we had best Adjourn immediately to our Council-Chamber;
Chuse some Potent Prince for Mediator,
And Garantee— Fix upon the place of Treaty,
Dispatch our Plenipos, and whip up the Peace
Like an Oyster. For under the Rose, my Confederates,
Here is such a damn'd Discount upon our Bills,
I'm afraid, if we stand it out another Campaign,
We must live upon slender Subsistance.

div.stage: Enter a Countrey Gentleman, who walks too and fro, looking angerly upon Aesop.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Have you any business with me, Sir?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: — I can't tell whether I have or not.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: You seem disturb'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I'm always so, at the sight of a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Pray what may it be, that gives you so great an Antipathy to 'em?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: My Profession.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Honesty.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: — 'Tis an honest Profession.
I hope, Sir, for the general good of Mankind, you are in some Publick Employment.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: So I am, Sir— no thanks to the Court.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: You are then, I suppose, Employ'd by—

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: My Countrey.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Who have made you—

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: A Senator.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Sir, I Reverence you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Sir, you may Reverence as low as you please. But I shall spare none of you. Sir, I am intrusted by my Countrey with above ten thousand of their Grievances, and in order to Redress 'em, my design is, to hang ten thousand Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: Why, 'tis making short work, I must confess.
But are you sure, Sir, that wou'd do't?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Sure.— Ay, sure.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Why the whole Countrey says so, and I at the Head of 'em.
Now, let me see who dares say the Contrary.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Not I truly. But Sir, if you won't take it ill, I'll ask you a Question or two.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Sir, I shall take ill what please. And if you, or e'er a Courtier of you all, pretend the contrary, I say, its a breach of Priviledge—
Now put your Qestion if you think fit.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Why, then Sir, with all due regard to your Character, and your Priviledge too. I wou'd be glad to know, what you chiefly complain of?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why, Sir, I do chiefly complain. That we have
A great many Ships, and very little Trade:
A great many Tenants, and very little Money:
A great many Souldiers, and very little Fighting.
A great many Gazettes, and little good News.
A great many States-Men, and very little Wisdom.
A great many Parsons, and not an ounce of Religion.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Why, truly Sir, I do confess these are Grievances very well worth your Redressing. I perceive you are truly sensible of our Diseases, but I'm afraid you are a little out in the Cure.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Sir, I perceive you take me for a Country-Physician: But you shall find, Sir, that a Country-Doctor, is able to deal with a Court-Quack; and to shew you, that I do understand something of the State of the Body Politick, I will tell you, Sir, that I have heard a Wise Man say, The Court is the Stomach of the Nation, in which, if the business be not thoroughly digested, the whole Carcass will be in disorder. Now, Sir, I do find by the Latitude of the Members, and the Vapours that fly into the Head, that this same Stomach is full of Indigestions, which must be remov'd. And therefore, Sir, I am come Post to Town with my Head full of Crocus Mem. and design to give the Court a Vomit.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Sir, the Physick you mention, tho' necessary sometimes, is of too violent a Nature, to be us'd without a great deal of Caution. I'm afraid you are a little too rash in your Prescriptions. Is it not possible you may be mistaken in the Cause of the Distemper.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir, I do not think it possible, I shou'd be mistaken in any thing.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, have you been long a Senator?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Have you been much about Town?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Have you Convers'd much with Men of Business?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Have you made any serious enquiry into the present Disorders of the Nation.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Have you ever heard what the Men now employ'd in business, have to say for themselves?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: How then do you know they deserve to be punish'd, for the present disorders in your Affairs?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I'll tell you how I know.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: I wou'd be glad to hear.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Why, I know by this— I know it I say, by this— That I'm sure on't—
And to give you demonstration that I'm sure on't, there is not one Man in a good Post in the Nation— but I'd give my Vote to hang him: Now I hope you are convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.l: As for example. The first Minister of State:
Why wou'd you hang him?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Because he gives bad Council.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Why they say so.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: And who wou'd you put in his room?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: One that wou'd give better.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: My self.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: The Secretary of State: Why wou'd you hang him?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Because he has not good intelligence.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I have heard so.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: And who wou'd you put in his Place?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: My Father.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: The Treasurer, why would you hang him?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Because he does n't understand his Business.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I dreamt so.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: And who would you have succeed him?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: My Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: The Admiral: why would you hang him?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Because he has not destroyed the Enemies.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: How do you know he could do it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Why, I believe so.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: And who would you have Command in his stead?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: My Brother.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: And the General: why would you hang him?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Because he took ne'er a Town last Campaign.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: And how do you know 'twas in his power?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Why I don't care a Sous whether it was in's power or not. But I have a Son at home, a brave chapping Lad; he has been Captain in the Militia this twelve months, and I'd be glad to see him in his Place. What do you stare for, Sir? ha? I gad I tell you he'd scour all the Devils. He's none of your Fencers; none of your Sa, Sa men. Numphs is downright; that's his Play. You may see his Courage in his Face. He has a pair of Cheeks like two Bladders; a Nose as flat as your Hand, and a Forehead like a Bull.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: In short, Sir, I find if you and your Family were provided for, things would soon grow better than they do.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And so they wou'd, Sir, Clap me at the Head of the State, and Numphs at the Head of the Army; He with his Club Musquet, and I with a Club Head peice, we'd soon put an end to your business.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: I believe you wou'd indeed. And therefore since I happen to be acquainted with your extraordinary Abilities, I am resolv'd to give the King an account of you, and employ my Interest with him, that you and your Son may have the Posts you desire.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Will you by the Lord?— Give me your fist, Sir— the only honest Courtier that ever I met with in my Life.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: But, Sir, when I have done you this mighty peice of Service, I shall have a small request to beg of you, which I hope you won't refuse me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: what's that?

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Why 'tis in behalf of the two Officers who are to be displac'd, to make room for you and your Son.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: The Secretary and the General?

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: The same. 'Tis pity they should be quite out of business; I must therefore desire you'll let me recommend one of 'em to you for your Bailiff, and t'other for your Huntsman.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: My Bailiff and my Huntsman?— Sir, that's not to be granted.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Pray why?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Why?— Because one wou'd ruin my Land, and t'other wou'd spoil my Fox-Hounds.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Why do you think so?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Why do I think so?— These Courtiers will ask the strangest Questions—
Why Sir, do you think that Men bred up to the State, and the Army, can understand the business of Ploughing and Hunting.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: I did not know but they might.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: How cou'd you think so?

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Because I see men bred up to Ploughing and Hunting, understand the business of the State and the Army.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I'm shot— I han't one word to say for my self— I never was so caught in my Life.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: I perceive, Sir, by your Looks, what I have said has made some impression upon you; and wou'd perhaps do more if you wou'd give it leave.

Taking his Hand.] Come, Sir tho' I am a stranger to you, I can be your Friend; My Favour at Court does not hinder me from being a Lover of my Country. 'Tis my Nature, as well as Principles, to be pleas'd with the prosperity of mankind: I wish all things happy, and my study is to make 'em so.

The Distempers of the Government (which I own are great) have employ'd the stretch of my Understanding, and the deepest of my thoughts, to penetrate the Cause, and to find out the
Remedy. But alas! all the product of my study is this; That I find there is too near a Resemblance between the Diseases of the State and those of the Body; for the most expert Minister to become a greater Master in one than the College in t'other. And how far their Skill extends, you may see by this Lump upon my Back. Allowances in all Professions there must be, since 'tis weak Man that is the weak Professor. Believe me, Senator, for I have seen the Proof on't. The longest Beard amongst us is a Fool. Cou'd you but stand behind the Curtain, and there observe the secret Springs of State; you'd see in all the Good or Evil that attends it, Ten Ounces of Chance for One Grain either of Wisdom or Roguery.

You'd see perhaps, a Venerable Statesman, sit fast asleep in a great Downy Chair; whilst in that soft Vacation of his thought, Blind, Chance (or what at least we blindly call so) shall so dispose a thousand secret Wheels, that when he wakes, he needs but write his Name, to publish to the World some blest Event, for which his Statue shall be rais'd in Brass.

Perhaps a moment thence, you shall behold him torturing his Brain: His thoughts all stretcht upon the Wrack for Publick Service. The live-long Night; when all the World's at rest, consum'd in Care, and watching for their safety, when by a Whirlwind in his Fate, in spight of him, some mischief shall befall 'em, for which a furious Sentence strait shall pass, and they shall Vote him to the Scaffold. Even thus uncertain are the Rewards and Punishments; and even thus little do the People know when 'tis the Statesman merits one or t'other.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Now do I believe I am beginning to be a wise man; for I never till now perceiv'd I was a Fool. But do you then really believe, Sir, our Men in Business do the best they can?

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Many of 'em do: some perhaps do not. But this you may depend upon; He that is out of business is the worst Judge in the World of him that is in: First, because he seldom knows any thing of the matter; and secondly, because he always desires to get his place.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And so, Sir, you turn the Tables upon the Plaintiff, and play, the Fool and Knave at his Door.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: If I do him wrong I'm sorry for't. Let him Examine himself, he'll find whether I do or not.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
— Examine?— I think I have had enough of that already. There's nothing left, that I know of, but to give Sentence: And truly I think there's no great difficulty in that. A very pretty Fellow I am indeed. Here am I come bellowing and roaring, 200. Miles Post, to find my self an Ass; when with one quarter of an hours consideration, I might have made the self same Discovery, without going over my Threshold. Well! if ever they send me on their Errand, to reform the State again, I'll be damn'd. But this I'll do: I'll go
home and reform my Family if I can: Them I'm sure I know: There's my Father's a peevish Old Coxcomb. There's my Uncle's a Drunken Old Sot: There's my Brother's a Cowardly Bully, Son Numphs is a Lubberly Whelp: I've a great Ramping Daughter, that stares like a Heifer, and a Wife that's a Slatternly Sow.

div.stage: Enter a Young Gay Airy Beau, who stands smiling contemptibly upon Aesop.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Fool.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: That's impossible;— for if thou wer't, thoud'st think thy self a Wise Man.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: So I do— This is my own Opinion— the t'other's my Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Aesop
sp.p: gazing after him.] Have you any business with me, Sir?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Sir, I have Business with no body— Pleasure's my study.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: An Odd Fellow this— Pray Sir, who are you?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I can't tell—

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: — Do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No Sir: I'm a Favourite at Court, and I neither know my self, nor any body else.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Are you in any Imployment?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yes—

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I don't know the Name on't.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: You know the Business on't I hope?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That I do— the Business of it is— to— put in a Deputy, and receive the Money.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: — Pray what may be your Name?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Empty.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In the Side-Box.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: What do you do there?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I Ogle the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: To what purpose?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To no purpose.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Why then do you do it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Because they like it, and I like it.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Wherein consists the Pleasure?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In Playing the Fool.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: — Pray Sir, what Age are you?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Five and Twenty— my Body— my Head's about Fifteen.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Is your Father living?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Dead, thank God.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Has he been long so?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Positively yes.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Where were you brought up?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: At School.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: What School?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The School of Venus.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Were you ever at the University?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: What study did you follow there?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: My Bed-Maker.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: How long did you stay?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Till I had lost my Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Why did you come away?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Because I was expell'd.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Where did you go then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To Court.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Who took care of your Education there?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A Whore and a Dancing-Master.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: What did you gain by them?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A Minuet, and the Pox.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Have you an Estate?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I had.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: What's become on't?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Spent.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In a Twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: But how?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why, In Dressing, Drinking, Whoring, Claps, Dice and Scriveners. What do you think of me now, Old Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Pray what do you think of your self?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I don't think at all: I know how to bestow my time better.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Are you Married?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No— have you ever a Daughter to bestow upon me?

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: She wou'd be well bestow'd.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why, I'm a strong young Dog, you Old Put you; she may be worse coupled—

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Have you then a mind to a Wife, Sir?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yaw myn Heer.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: What wou'd you do with her?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why, I'd take care of her Affairs, rid her of all her troubles, her Maidenhead and her Portion.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: And pray what sort of Wife wou'd you be willing to throw your self away upon?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why, upon one that has Youth, Beauty, Quality, Vertue, Wit and Money.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: And how may you be qualified your self, to back you in your Pretensions to such a one?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why, I am qualified, with— a Periwig— a Snuff-box,— a Feather,— a— Smooth Face,— a Fool's Head— and a Patch.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: But One Question more: What Settlements can you make?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Settlements?— Why, if she be a very Great Heiress indeed, I believe I may settle— my self upon her for Life, and my Pox upon her Children for ever.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: 'Tis enough; you may expect I'll serve you, If it lies in my way. But I wou'd not have you relie too much upon your Success, because People sometimes are mistaken— As for Example—

lg.l: An Ape there was of Nimble Parts,
A great Intruder into Hearts,
As Brisk, and Gay, and full of Air,
As you, or I, or any here;
Rich in his Dress, of splendid shew,
And with an Head like any Beau.
Eternal Mirth was in his Face;
Where'er he went,
He was content,
So Fortune had but Kindly sent
Some Ladies— and a Looking-glass.
Encouragement they always gave him,
Encouragement to play the Fool;
For soon they found it was a Tool;
Wou'd hardly be so much in Love,
But that the Mumbling of a Glove,
Or tearing of a Fan, wou'd save him.
These Bounties he accepts as Proof,
Of feats done by his Wit and Youth,
He gives their freedom gone for ever;
Concludes each Female heart undone,
Except that very happy one:
To which he'd please to do the favour,
In short, so smooth his matters went.
He guest, where'er his thoughts were bent,
The Lady he must carry.
So put on a fine New Cravat,
He comb'd his Wig, he cock't his Hat,
And gave it out, He'd Marry;
But here, alas! he found to's Cost,
He had reckon'd long without his Host;
For where soe'er he made the Attack,
Poor Pug with shame was beaten back.
The first Fair she he had in Chace,
Was a Young Cat, extreamly Rich,
Her Mother was a Noted Witch;
So had the Daughter prov'd but Civil,
He had been related to the Devil.
But when he came
To urge his Flame,
She scratch'd him o'er the Face.
With that he went among the Bitches,
Such as had Beauty, Wit and Riches,
And swore Miss Maulkin, to her Cost,
Shou'd quickly see what she had lost:
But the poor Unlucky Swain
Miss'd his Shepherdess again;
His Fate was to miscarry,
It was his Destiny to find,
That Cats and Dogs are of a mind,
When Monkeys come to Marry.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: 'Tis very well;— 'Tis very well, Old Spark, I say, 'tis very well— Because I han't a pair of Plod-Shooes, and a Dirty Shirt, you think a Woman won't venture upon me for a Husband— Why now to shew you, Old Father, how little you Philosophers know of the Ladies,— I'll tell you an Advanture of a Friend of mine.
sp.l: A Band, a Bob Wig, and a Feather.
Attack'd a Ladies heart together:
The Band in a most Learned Plea,
Made up of Deep Philosophy,
Told her, if she wou'd please to wed,
A Reverend Beard, and take instead
Of Vigorous Youth,
Old Solemn Truth,
With Books and Morals into Bed,
How happy she wou'd be.

lg.l: The Bob, he talkt of Management,
What wond'rous Blessings Heaven sent
On Care, and Pains, and Industry,
And truly he must be so free,
To own, he thought your Airy Beaux,
With Powder'd Wigs and Dancing Shoes,
Were good for nothing (mend his soul).
But prate, and talk, and play the Fool.
He said it was Wealth gave Joy and Mirth,
And these be the dearest Wife
Of one who labour'd all his Life,
To make a Mine of Gold his own,
And not spend 6 pence when he'ad done,
Was Heaven upon Earth.
When these two Blades had done, d'ye see,
The Feather, (as it might be me)
Steps out, Sir, from behind the Skreen,
With such an Air, and such a Mien,—
Look you, Old Gentleman, in short,
He quickly spoil'd the Statesmens sport.
It prov'd such Sun-shine weather,
That you must know, at the first Beck,
The Lady leapt about his Neck,
And off they went together.

sp.p: To Aesop.] There's a Tale for your Tale, Old Dad; and so— Serviteur.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Part.
